title: Honors Survey of World Literature:Ancient World through the Sixteenth Century
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: A survey of world literature from the ancient world through the 16th. Students will study works of prose, poetry, drama, and fiction in relation to their historical and cultural contexts. Texts will be selected from a diverse group of authors and traditions.

title: Honors Survey of World Literature- 17th Century through the Present
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: A survey of world literature from the 17th century to the present. Students will study works of prose, poetry, drama, and fiction in relation to their historical and cultural contexts. Texts will be selected from a diverse group of authors and traditions. International Studies Area of Concentration course.

title: Honors Forms of Literature
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: The study of one or more literary genres including, but not limited to, poetry, fiction, drama, and film. Other forms might include mythic and religious writing, autobiographies and memoirs, and polemics. Readings vary. Instructors are free to choose their own emphasis.

title: Honors Mexican-American Literature
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: A survey of Mexican-American literature from its origins to the present covering the major literary genres - the essay, epic poetry, lyric poetry, the short story, novel, drama, and folk literature.

title: Introduction to Engineering
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: An introduction to the engineering profession with emphasis on technical communication and team-based engineering design.

title: Engineering Graphics I
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: Introduction to computer-aided drafting using CAD software and sketching to generate two- and three-dimensional drawings based on the conventions of engineering graphical communication; topics include spatial relationships, multi-view projections and sectioning, dimensioning, graphical presentation of data, and fundamentals of computer graphics.

title: Electric Circuits I
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: Laboratory experiments supporting theoretical principles presented in ENGR 2305 involving DC and AC circuit theory, network theorems, time, and frequency domain circuit analysis. Introduction to principles and operation of basic laboratory equipment; laboratory report preparation. ENGR 2305 and ENGR 2105 must be taken concurrently.

title: Engineering Mechanics: Statics
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: Basic theory of engineering mechanics, using calculus, involving the description of forces, moments, and couples acting on stationary engineering structures; equilibrium in two and three dimensions; free-body diagrams; friction; centroids; centers of gravity; and moments of inertia.

title: Engineering Mechanics:Dynamics
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: Basic theory of engineering mechanics, using calculus, involving the motion of particles, rigid bodies, and systems of particles; Newton's Laws; work and energy relationships; principles of impulse and momentum; application of kinetics and kinematics to the solution of engineering problems.

title: Programming for Engineers
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: Programming principles and techniques for matrix and array operations, equation solving, and numeric simulations applied to engineering problems and visualization of engineering information; platforms include spreadsheets, symbolic algebra packages, engineering analysis software, and laboratory control software.

title: Electric Circuits I
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: Principles of electrical circuits and systems. Basic circuit elements (resistance, inductance, mutual inductance, capacitance, independent and dependent controlled voltage, and current sources). Topology of electrical networks; Kirchhoff ’s laws; node and mesh analysis; DC circuit analysis; operational amplifiers; transient and sinusoidal steady-state analysis; AC circuit analysis; first- and second-order circuits; Bode plots; and use of computer simulation software to solve circuit problems. ENGR 2305 and ENGR 2105 must be taken concurrently.

title: Engineering Economics
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, North Harris, Online,
description: Methods used for determining the comparative financial desirability of engineering alternatives. Provides the student with the basic tools required to analyze engineering alternatives in terms of their worth and cost, an essential element of engineering practice. The student is introduced to the concept of the time value of money and the methodology of basic engineering economy techniques. The course will address some aspects of sustainability and will provide the student with the background to enable them to pass the Engineering Economy portion of the Fundamentals of Engineering exam.

title: Mechanics of Materials
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: Stresses, deformations, stress-strain relationships, torsions, beams, shafts, columns, elastic deflections in beams, combined loading, and combined stresses.

title: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics I
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: Fundamental concepts of energy and thermodynamics (e.g., temperature, thermodynamic equilibrium, and heat) will be introduced; the course emphasizes techniques in the application of the fundamentals of thermodynamics to various processes as they frequently occur in chemical and bimolecular engineering. Provides the basic skills and tools necessary in designing and analyzing real-life engineering systems. Serves as preparation for other advanced courses in thermodynamics, energy conversion, heat transfer, etc.

title: Electrical Circuits I
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: Principles of electrical circuits and systems. Basic circuit elements (resistance, inductance, mutual inductance, capacitance, independent and dependent controlled voltage, and current sources). Topology of electrical networks; Kirchhoff's laws; node and mesh analysis; DC circuit analysis; operational amplifiers; transient and sinusoidal steady-state analysis; AC circuit analysis; first- and second-order circuits; Bode plots; and use of computer simulation software to solve circuit problems. Laboratory experiments supporting theoretical principles involving DC and AC circuit theory, network theorems, time, and frequency domain circuit analysis. Introduction to principles and operation of basic laboratory equipment; laboratory report preparation. (1410015110).

title: Introduction to Digital Systems
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: Introduction to theory and design of digital logic, circuits, and systems. Number systems, operations and codes; logic gates; Boolean Algebra and logic simplification; Karnaugh maps; combinational logic; functions of combinational Logic; flip-flops and related devices; counters; shift registers; sequential logic; memory and storage. Basic laboratory experiments supporting theoretical principles involving design, construction, and analysis of combinational and sequential digital circuits and systems, including logic gates, adders, multiplexers, encoders, decoders, arithmetic logic units, latches, flip-flops, registers, and counters; preparation of laboratory reports.

title: Honors Engineering Graphics I
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: Introduction to computer- aided drafting using CAD software and sketching to generate two- and three-dimensional drawings based on the conventions of engineering graphical communication; topics include spatial relationships, multi-view projections and sectioning, dimensioning, graphical presentation of data, and fundamentals of computer graphics.

title: Strength of Materials
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball,
description: Study of the relationship between externally applied forces and internally induced stresses and the resulting deformations in structural members.

title: Statics
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: Explanation of forces acting on structures to create equilibrium. Includes the concepts of friction, moments, couples, centroids, and moment of inertia.

title: Co-op Engineering Tech Technician
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: Career-related activities encountered in the student's area of specialization offered through an individualized agreement among the college, employer, and student. Under the supervision of the college and the employer, the student combines classroom learning with work experience. Includes a lecture component.

title: Environmental Science I
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: Interdisciplinary study of both natural (biology, chemistry, geology) and social (economics, politics, ethics) sciences as they apply to the environment.  Focus is on the role of science in addressing global environmental concerns. Concepts include ethics, policy, matter, energy, species biodiversity, ecology, human populations, food and agriculture.  Practical laboratory experience emphasizes the application of fundamental principles of biology and chemistry as well as critical thinking and analysis. Lab required.

title: Environmental Science II
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: Continued interdisciplinary study of both natural (biology, chemistry, geology) and social (economics, politics, ethics) sciences as they apply to the environment.  Focus on energy issues, global warming, ozone loss, land use, conservation and managementof resources, deforestation, biodiversity, waste, and sustainable practices. Lab required.

title: Honors Environmental Science I
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: Interdisciplinary study of both natural (biology, chemistry, geology) and social (economics, politics, ethics) sciences as they apply to the environment.  Focus is on the role of science in addressing global environmental concerns. Concepts include ethics, policy, matter, energy, species biodiversity, ecology, human populations, food and agriculture.  Practical laboratory experience emphasizes the application of fundamental principles of biology and chemistry as well as critical thinking and analysis. Lab required.

title: Honors Environmental Science II
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: Continued interdisciplinary study of both natural (biology, chemistry, geology) and social (economics, politics, ethics) sciences as they apply to the environment. Focus on energy issues, global warming, ozone loss, land use, conservation and management of resources, deforestation, biodiversity, waste, and sustainable practices. Lab required.

title: ESOL Language Skills Workshop
department: ESOL - English for Speakers of Other Languages
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description:
This course refines the use of communication skills necessary for personal, academic, and business communication. It incorporates negotiated student/instructor-generated content and accommodates individual goals in a workshop format. Open lab available. This course focuses on Standard English grammar usage for academic purposes. Open only to non-native speakers. This course carries institutional credit but will not transfer and may not be used to meet degree requirements.

Course Objectives
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to meet the following outcomes at the appropriate level:
1. Comprehend and produce oral and written language.
2. Improve specific language skills or a set of skills for use in various social, academic, and workplace settings.
3. Respond to written and spoken language in various formats.

title: ESOL Integrated Reading/Writing
department: ESOL - English for Speakers of Other Languages
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description:
Integration of critical reading and academic writing skills. 
Successful completion of this course fulfills TSI requirements for reading and/or writing. This course carries institutional credit but will not transfer and will not be used to meet degree requirements.

Course Objectives
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to meet the following outcomes at the advanced level:
1. Locate explicit textual information, draw complex inferences, and describe, analyze, and evaluate the information within and across multiple texts of varying lengths. 
2. Comprehend and use vocabulary effectively in oral communication, reading, and writing. 
3. Identify and analyze the audience, purpose, and message across a variety of texts. 
4. Describe and apply insights gained from reading and writing a variety of texts. 
5. Compose a variety of texts that demonstrate reading comprehension, clear focus, logical development of ideas, and use of appropriate language that advance the writer’s purpose. 
6. Determine and use effective approaches and rhetorical strategies for given reading and writing situations. 
7. Generate ideas and gather information relevant to the topic and purpose, incorporating the ideas and words of other writers in student writing using established strategies.
8. Evaluate relevance and quality of ideas and information in recognizing, formulating, and developing a claim. 
9. Develop and use effective reading and revision strategies to strengthen the writer’s ability to compose college-level writing assignments. 
10. Recognize and apply the conventions of Standard English in reading and writing.

title: ESOL Integrated Reading and Writing Co-Requisite with HIST 1301
department: ESOL - English for Speakers of Other Languages
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description:
Integration of critical reading and academic writing skills. Successful completion of this course fulfills TSI requirements for reading and/or writing. This course is linked with HIST 1301 and must be taken at the same time. ESOL 0331 is designed to support success in HIST 1301. This course carries institutional credit but will not transfer and will not be used to meet degree requirements.

9. Develop and use effective reading and revision strategies to strengthen the writer’s ability to compose college-level writing assignments. 
10. Recognize and apply the conventions of Standard English in reading and writing.

title: ESOL Integrated Reading and Writing Co-Requisite with ENGL 1301
department: ESOL - English for Speakers of Other Languages
campus: North Harris, CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description:

ESOL 0332 is designed to support success in ENGL 1301. This course carries institutional credit but will not transfer and will not be used to meet degree requirements.

title: ESOL Reading & Vocabulary I
department: ESOL - English for Speakers of Other Languages
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description:
This course for beginning English-language students develops English reading proficiency and vocabulary for academic, career, or personal purposes and prepares them to function in a multicultural, multilingual society.  Materials are vocabulary-controlled and based on concrete topics. Students practice reading and comprehending simple short stories and articles, writing related sentences, and developing basic library skills. Focus is on literal comprehension and developing a personally relevant vocabulary base. Students who enroll in this course should have basic literacy skills in their native language and be familiar with Roman script. This course carries institutional credit but will not transfer and may not be used to meet degree requirements.

Course Objectives
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to meet the following outcomes at the basic level:
1. Identify the stated main idea, supporting details, and basic audience of a short passage on a familiar topic.
2. Comprehend and identify the author's purpose.
3. Extract basic information and make basic inferences from text and simple illustrations such as graphs and charts.
4. Respond orally and in writing to a variety of basic level texts.
5. Comprehend and use basic vocabulary; determine the meaning of unfamiliar vocabulary from context.
6. Demonstrate knowledge of cultural and historical references to American society in written materials.
7. Use print or online monolingual English resource material to develop basic dictionary skills and build basic vocabulary.

title: ESOL Reading & Vocabulary II
department: ESOL - English for Speakers of Other Languages
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description:
This course for English-language students develops reading proficiency and vocabulary skills for academic, career, or personal purposes and prepares them to function in a multicultural, multilingual society. The course includes practice in reading using materials based on high interest topics and comprehending multi-paragraph descriptive and narrative articles, stories, reports, and dictionary entries. Focus is on literal comprehension, word analysis, vocabulary expansion, dictionary skills, and the use of library resources. Writing is required to complement varied reading activities. This course carries institutional credit but will not transfer and may not be used to meet degree requirements.

Course Objectives:
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to meet the following outcomes at the low-intermediate level:
1. Apply reading skills to comprehend and identify the stated main idea and supporting details.
2. Interpret a sequence of events, audience, purpose in a paragraph or simple multi-paragraph text and distinguish between fact and opinion.
3. Extract literal information and make basic inferences from text and from charts, graphs, photographs, and other illustrations.
4. Respond orally and in writing to a variety of low-intermediate level texts.
5. Comprehend and use expanding vocabulary base; determine the meaning of unfamiliar vocabulary from context.
6. Demonstrate knowledge of cultural and historical references to American society in written materials.
7. Apply a variety of pre-reading strategies such as previewing, skimming, scanning, and predicting to set a purpose for reading and to increase reading comprehension.
8. Use print or online monolingual English resource material to identify meaning/s, form, use, and pronunciation of new vocabulary.

title: ESOL Reading & Vocabulary III
department: ESOL - English for Speakers of Other Languages
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description:
This course continues to develop English-language students' reading and higher order thinking skills necessary for college readiness. The course includes extensive practice in reading and comprehending multi-page articles, narratives, reports, editorials, opinion essays, and reference materials on a variety of topics, and writing related responses. Focus is on interpretation of factual material, drawing inferences and conclusions, and paraphrasing and summarizing selected passages. Writing is required to complement reading activities. This course carries institutional credit but will not transfer and may not be used to meet degree requirements.

Course Objectives
Upon successful completion of this course, students will meet the following outcomes at the intermediate level:
1. Locate stated or implied main ideas and supporting details, draw inferences, and evaluate information within and across a variety of intermediate level texts.
2. Continue to expand and use vocabulary; determine meaning of unfamiliar and familiar words in new contexts by using context clues and word forms.
3. Extract both literal and inferential information from text and graphics, charts, diagrams, flowcharts, photographs, and other illustrations.
4. Identify and analyze audience, purpose and message in intermediate level texts.
5. Outline and summarize passages, paraphrase ideas, and describe and apply insights gained from reading a variety of texts.
6. Select and use resource materials to identify meaning/s, pronunciation, grammatical forms, and appropriate use of unfamiliar vocabulary.

title: ESOL Reading & Vocabulary IV
department: ESOL - English for Speakers of Other Languages
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description:
Development of reading and higher order thinking skills necessary for college readiness. This course carries institutional credit but will not transfer and will not be used to meet degree requirements.

Course Objectives
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to meet the following outcomes at the high-intermediate level:
1. Locate explicit textual information, draw complex inferences, and describe, analyze, and evaluate the information within and across multiple texts of varying lengths.
2. Comprehend and use vocabulary effectively in oral communication, reading, and writing.
3. Describe, analyze, and evaluate information within and across a range of texts.
4. Identify and analyze the audience, purpose, and message across a variety of texts.
5. Describe and apply insights gained from reading a variety of texts.
6. Use main idea and details from a variety of course-appropriate written texts to develop short responses, summaries, graphic organizers, and outlines.

title: ESOL Reading & Vocabulary V
department: ESOL - English for Speakers of Other Languages
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description:
This course develops English reading proficiency and vocabulary for academic, career, or personal purposes in speakers of languages other than English and prepares them to function in a multicultural, multilingual society. This course carries institutional credit but will not transfer and will not be used to meet degree requirements.  This course fulfills TSI requirement for Reading.

Course Objectives
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to meet the following outcomes at the advanced level: 
1. Comprehend and summarize texts, including the identification of main idea, supporting details, audience, and purpose of text. 
2. Interpret and critically analyze author’s bias, purpose, and perspective in academic materials. 
3. Make inferences and draw conclusions from a variety of college level texts. 
4. Respond critically, orally and in writing, to various kinds of college level texts. 
5. Understand and use academic vocabulary and linguistically complex structures across a variety of disciplines and genres. 
6. Demonstrate knowledge of cultural and historical references to American society in written materials.

title: ESOL Writing I
department: ESOL - English for Speakers of Other Languages
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description:
In this course, beginning English-language students focus on strategies and techniques of writing and composition. Students will develop, practice and apply the basic structures of English to perform simple writing tasks.  Students who enroll in this course should have basic literacy skills in their native language and be familiar with Roman script. This course carries institutional credit but will not transfer and may not be used to meet degree requirements.

Course Objectives
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to meet the following outcomes at the basic level:
1. Write a clear, well-organized paragraph using a logical sequence in a prescribed rhetorical mode, such as simple descriptions and narrations about familiar topics.
2. Demonstrate ability to use the writing process by generating ideas, drafting, revising, and editing.
3. Demonstrate functional vocabulary knowledge in a variety of contexts.
4.  Write simple & compound sentences. 
5. Follow basic conventions of capitalization and punctuation to demonstrate understanding of sentence boundaries and follow basic spelling conventions.
6. Use basic skills related to research-based academic writing, such as writing a collection of sentences based on interviews with outside sources, writing concluding sentences which paraphrase topic sentences or including antonyms and synonyms in written work.

title: ESOL Writing II
department: ESOL - English for Speakers of Other Languages
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description:
In this course English-language students focus on strategies and techniques of writing and composition. Students will increase proficiency in the writing skills necessary for basic personal, academic, and professional communication. Students use process writing techniques to write simple paragraphs and gain mastery in the use of the basic structures of the language. This course carries institutional credit but will not transfer and may not be used to meet degree requirements.

Course Objectives
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to meet the following outcomes at the low-intermediate level
1. Write a short, well-organized paragraph with topic sentence, support, and conclusion in several rhetorical modes such as descriptive, narrative, and process. 
2. Demonstrate ability to use the writing process by generating (e.g., brainstorming and mapping) and organizing ideas, drafting, revising, and editing.
3. Demonstrate functional vocabulary knowledge in a variety of contexts.
4. Write simple, compound and complex sentences.
5. Edit for vocabulary and sentence structure.
6. Use basic skills related to research-based academic writing, such as using basic methods for integrating quotations, utilizing reporting verbs, or informally referencing ideas from outside sources.

title: ESOL Writing III
department: ESOL - English for Speakers of Other Languages
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description:
In this course, English-language students will develop college-level writing, focusing on idea generation, drafting, organization, revision, and utilization of standard English. This course continues to develop students' writing skills for personal, academic and professional purposes. Students use more sophisticated grammar structures in writing well-developed paragraphs using process writing techniques. This course carries institutional credit but will not transfer and may not be used to meet degree requirements.

Course Objectives
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to meet the following outcomes at the intermediate level
1. Compose a variety of paragraphs and short (three-four paragraph) essays that are well organized and developed with adequate support.
2. Determine and use a variety of rhetorical modes such as comparison/contrast, definition/example, and opinion.
3. Use pre-writing techniques to generate and organize ideas, & incorporate the ideas and words of other writers, such as including a quote or a statistic in a hook using established strategies at the intermediate level.
4. Evaluate relevance and quality of ideas and information to formulate and develop a claim at the intermediate level.
5. Revise writing for content and organization.
6. Edit for vocabulary, sentence structure, and paragraph form.
7. Write simple, compound, and complex sentences & identify compound-complex sentence.

title: ESOL Writing IV
department: ESOL - English for Speakers of Other Languages
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description:
This course focuses on the development of college-level writing focusing on idea generation, drafting, organization, revision, and utilization of standard English. This course carries institutional credit but will not transfer and will not be used to meet degree requirements.

Course Objectives
Upon successful completion of this course, students will meet the following outcomes at the high-intermediate level:
1. Compose a variety of multi-paragraph essays that are well-organized and cohesive, contain adequate support, and use accurate idiomatic expressions, collocations, and fixed expressions to express ideas clearly.
2. Determine and use a variety of rhetorical modes such as comparison/contrast, cause/effect, and argumentative.
3. Generate ideas and gather information relevant to the topic and purpose and incorporate others' ideas appropriately in writing using established strategies.
4. Evaluate relevance and quality of ideas and information to formulate and develop a claim.
5. Revise essays for content and organization.
6. Edit for vocabulary, grammar, and mechanics.
7. Write coherent sentences in a variety of patterns appropriate for academic writing.

title: ESOL Writing V
department: ESOL - English for Speakers of Other Languages
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description:
This course focuses on strategies and techniques of writing and composition. Open only to non-native speakers. This course carries institutional credit but will not transfer and will not be used to meet degree requirements. This course fulfills TSI requirement for Writing.

Course Objectives
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to meet the following outcomes at the advanced level: 
1. Write a clear, well-organized, multi-paragraph essay using a logical sequence in a prescribed rhetorical mode. 
2. Demonstrate ability to use the writing process by generating ideas, drafting, revising, and editing. 
3. Demonstrate functional vocabulary knowledge in a variety of contexts at a level appropriate for college level courses. 
4. Write coherent and cohesive sentences in a variety of common patterns. 
5. Recognize and use proper English mechanics. 
6. Demonstrate proficiency in basic skills related to research-based academic writing, such as paraphrasing,  summarizing, quoting, and citing sources according to prescribed style guidelines.

title: ESOL Oral Communication II
department: ESOL - English for Speakers of Other Languages
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description:
This course develops listening and speaking skills in speakers of languages other than English and prepares them to function in educational, vocational and/or personal English-speaking contexts. English-language students will increase proficiency and communicate with a growing degree of fluency, using newly acquired vocabulary with some degree of accuracy, and master basic language functions.  Students acquire and practice strategies for comprehending statements and short spoken passages. This course carries institutional credit but will not transfer and may not be used to meet degree requirements.

Course Objectives
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to meet the following outcomes at the low-intermediate level:
1. Respond to spoken conversations and short oral texts that use familiar vocabulary in new contexts by answering comprehension questions correctly. 
2. Give a short oral presentation on a familiar topic.
3. Speak with fluency, using grammar, pronunciation, reductions, and contractions.
4. Demonstrate the ability to use a range of formal and informal language appropriate to context.
5. Ask and respond to simple questions using basic question and statement intonation patterns.
6. Assess own language production and use appropriate self-monitoring strategies such as rephrasing, re-directing, asking for clarification, and circumlocution.
7. Express possibility and necessity, give instructions, make requests, ask for clarification, and discuss plans at the low-intermediate level.
8. Demonstrate knowledge of a wide range of cultural conventions and references in oral and nonverbal communication .

title: ESOL Oral Communication III
department: ESOL - English for Speakers of Other Languages
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description:
This course continues to develop listening and speaking skills in speakers of languages other than English and prepares them to function in educational, vocational and/or personal English-speaking contexts. Students will be provided dynamic communicative practice to increase their degree of fluency, accuracy, and comprehension in listening and speaking skills. They develop skills at using functional language in a variety of relevant contexts. This course carries institutional credit but will not transfer and may not be used to meet degree requirements.

Course Objectives
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to meet the following outcomes at the intermediate level:
1. Respond to short audio listening segments by summarizing main ideas and details, answering questions, and discussing the topic.
2. Give an oral presentation on an assigned topic.
3. Speak with few hesitations and pauses, using level-appropriate grammar, pronunciation, and intonation.  
4. Demonstrate the ability to use a range of formal and informal language appropriate to context.
5. Participate in face-to-face conversations of routine questions, answers, and statements in familiar or unfamiliar contexts containing some unfamiliar vocabulary.
6. Assess own language production and use appropriate self -monitoring strategies such as rephrasing, re-directing, asking for clarification, and circumlocution.
7. Express abstract ideas, give advice and opinions, agree and disagree, express ability and possibility, and make comparisons and predictions.
8. Demonstrate knowledge of a wide range of cultural conventions and references in oral and nonverbal communication.

title: ESOL Advanced Listening and Speaking
department: ESOL - English for Speakers of Other Languages
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description:
This course develops listening and speaking skills in speakers of languages other than English and prepares them to function in educational, vocational and/or personal English-speaking contexts. This course carries institutional credit but will not transfer and will not be used to meet degree requirements.

Course Objectives
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to meet the following outcomes at the high-intermediate level: 
1. Demonstrate understanding of authentic oral texts (e.g., lectures, newscasts, podcasts) that contain sophisticated vocabulary and structures by successfully completing comprehension tasks, such as answering questions, note-taking, outlining, paraphrasing, summarizing, or evaluating the content, etc. [comprehension tasks such as identifying main, supporting ideas, and implied meaning are subsumed.] 
2. Plan and deliver formal oral presentations using appropriate vocabulary and syntax, recognizable organization, clear pronunciation, nonverbal cues, and appropriate volume and intonation, and respond appropriately to questions.
3. Speak with fluency, using complex and accurate language, clear pronunciation and prosodic elements (e.g., intonation, rhythm, word and sentence stress). 
4. Demonstrate the ability to use a range of formal and informal language appropriate to context.
5. Participate in discussions in formal and informal settings using active listening skills and making appropriate and extended comments. 
6. Assess own language production and use appropriate self-monitoring strategies such as rephrasing, re-directing, asking for clarification, and circumlocution. 
7. Analyze and evaluate oral expression by listening critically for elements that reflect an awareness of situation, audience, purpose, and diverse points of view.
8. Demonstrate knowledge of a wide range of cultural conventions and references in oral and nonverbal communication.

title: ESOL Grammar I
department: ESOL - English for Speakers of Other Languages
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description:
This course focuses on standard English grammar usage for academic purposes. Open only to non-native English speakers. Students develop control of fundamental structures including basic tenses, parts of speech and simple sentences. This course is linked with ESOL 0371 (ESOL Writing I) and must be taken concurrently (as a corequisite).  ESOL Grammar I is designed to support success in ESOL Writing I. This course carries institutional credit but will not transfer and will not be used to meet degree requirements.
Course Objectives
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to meet the following outcomes at the basic level:
1. Use basic verb tenses and voice with proficiency: present, past, and future, including the use of “there is/there are” and imperatives.
2. Use simple & compound sentences with phrases at the basic level. Use Yes/No and WH- questions. 
3. Use parts of speech: nouns, pronouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs, prepositions, interjections, conjunctions and determiners (quantifiers, articles, demonstratives, possessives) appropriately and with proficiency, with specific attention to: identifying and using count & non-count, subject pronouns, object pronouns, and demonstrative pronouns & possessive adjectives and possessive nouns.
4. Use appropriate word choice, word form, and word order with proficiency.

title: ESOL Grammar II
department: ESOL - English for Speakers of Other Languages
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description:
This course continues to focus on standard English grammar usage for academic purposes. Open only to non-native English speakers.  English Language learners will develop English grammar skills by extensive and varied practice that encourages English language development for academic purposes. Emphasis is placed on the use of verb tenses, modal verbs, nouns, adjectives and adverbs.  This course is linked with ESOL 0372 (ESOL Writing II), and must be taken concurrently (as a corequisite). ESOL Grammar II is designed to support success in ESOL Writing II. This course carries institutional credit but will not transfer and will not be used to meet degree requirements.

Course Objectives
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to meet the following outcomes at the low-intermediate level:
1. Use basic verb tenses and voice with proficiency in simple present, present progressive, simple past, and past progressive. 
2. Use simple, compound, and complex sentences structures including phrases and clauses with proficiency.
3. Appropriately use parts of speech: nouns, pronouns, verbs, prepositions, interjections, conjunctions, adjectives (including comparative and superlative adjectives), adverbs (including expressions of frequency and time) as well as determiners (quantifiers, articles, demonstratives, possessives) with proficiency.
4. Use appropriate word choice, word form, and word order with proficiency.
5. Use basic modal verbs.

title: ESOL Grammar III
department: ESOL - English for Speakers of Other Languages
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description:
This course continues to focus on Standard English grammar usage for academic purposes. Open only to non-native speakers. English-language learners will continue to develop the existing knowledge of grammatical structures and acquire new ones. Emphasis is placed on the complex verb tenses, passive voice, and compound sentences. This course will help students apply grammatical accuracy to their writing and speaking. This course carries institutional credit but will not transfer and will not be used to meet degree requirements.

Course Objectives
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to meet the following outcomes at the intermediate level:
1. Discriminate between the uses of simple present, present progressive, present perfect progressive, present perfect, simple past & simple future verb tenses. 
2. Identify and use verbs in the passive voice. 
3. Use a variety of modals.
4. Form sentences with simple time and conditional clauses.
5. Use basic infinitives and gerunds.
6. Use present and past participles.
7. Use appropriate word choice, word form, and word order with proficiency.

title: ESOL Grammar IV
department: ESOL - English for Speakers of Other Languages
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description:
This course continues to focus on Standard English grammar usage for academic purposes. Open only to non-native speakers. Students continue the study of grammatical structures required for quality oral and written academic communication. They develop skills in understanding form, meaning and usage of complex grammatical structures including gerunds and infinitives, conditionals and complex sentences with noun, adjective and adverb clauses. This course carries institutional credit but will not transfer and will not be used to meet degree requirements.

Course Objectives
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to meet the following outcomes at the high-intermediate level:
1. Use verb tenses and voice with proficiency, including discriminating between the uses of the past perfect, past progressive, past perfect progressive.
2. Use simple, compound, and complex sentence structures including phrases and adjective, noun, and adverb clauses with proficiency.
3. Use parts of speech (nouns, pronouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs, prepositions, interjections, conjunctions) and determiners (quantifiers, articles, demonstratives, possessives) appropriately and with proficiency.
4. Use appropriate word choice, word form, and word order with proficiency.
5. Use modals in present, past, and progressive tenses and passive voice.
6. Identify and use verbals: participles, gerunds and infinitives.
7. Identify and use causative verbs.
8. Use conditionals and the subjunctive.
9. Use direct and indirect speech

title: ESOL Grammar for Writing V
department: ESOL - English for Speakers of Other Languages
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description:
This course focuses on the development of college-level writing focusing on idea generation, drafting, organization, revision, and utilization of standard English. Students continue to focus on standard English grammar usage for academic purposes. Open only to non-native speakers. This course carries institutional credit but will not transfer and will not be used to meet degree requirements.

Course Objectives
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to meet the following outcomes at the advanced level:
1. Compose a variety of texts that demonstrate clear focus, the logical development of ideas, and the use of appropriate language that advances the writer’s purpose. 
2. Determine and use effective approaches and rhetorical strategies for given writing situations. 
3. Generate ideas and gather information relevant to the topic and purpose, incorporating the ideas and words of other writers in student writing using established strategies. 
4. Evaluate relevance and quality of ideas and information to formulate and develop a claim. 
5. Develop and use effective revision strategies to strengthen the writer’s ability to compose college-level writing assignments.
6. Edit writing to conform to the conventions of standard English.

title: eSports Event Planning
description: Topics address recently identified current events, skills, knowledges, and/or attitudes and behaviors pertinent to the technology or occupation and relevant to the professional development of the student. This course was designed to be repeated multiple times to improve student proficiency.

Under the supervision of the college and the employer, the student combines classroom learning with work experience. Includes a lecture component.

title: Contemporary Issues in eSports
description: Topics address recently identified current events, skills, knowledges, and/or attitudes and behaviors pertinent to the technology or occupation and relevant to the professional development of the student. This course was designed to be repeated multiple times to improve student proficiency.

title: Firefighter Agility and Fitness Preparation
description: Physical ability testing methods. Rigorous training in skills and techniques needed in typical fire department physical ability tests. Firefighter Agility and Fitness is 1 of 9 co-requisite courses to complete the Texas Commission on Fire Protection curriculum for Basic Structural Firefighter. Acceptance in this course is conditional to student acceptance of the stringent program policy and rules for successful completion. Course content includes introduction to entry level firefighter agility and fitness assessments (PAT); examines the importance of firefighter fitness in performance of the PAT; examines the importance of identifying the tasks, sequence, and rules of the PAT; provides application of the fitness capacity and test knowledge to local PAT performance.

title: Firefighter Agility and Fitness Preparation
description:
Physical ability testing methods. Rigorous training in skills and techniques needed in typical fire department physical ability tests. 
Firefighter Agility and Fitness Preparation is 1 of 9 required courses to complete the Texas Commission on Fire Protection curriculum for Basic Structural Firefighter; it is a co-requisite of the first semester of the firefighter certification program and prerequisite to the second semester. Acceptance in this course is conditional to student acceptance of the stringent program policy and rules for successful completion. Course content includes introduction firefighter functional fitness and the application of the concepts of cardiorespiratory, flexibility, strength, endurance training; introduces the connection between firefighter functional fitness and lifestyle habits; physically prepares the firefighter trainee for entry level firefighter agility and fitness assessments (PAT).

title: Special Topics in Fire Science/Firefighting - Principles of Fire/Emergency Services Safety&Survival
description: This course introduces the basic principles and history related to the national firefighter life safety initiatives, focusing on the need for cultural and behavior change throughout the emergency services.

title: Firefighter Certification I
description:
One in a series of courses in basic preparation for a new firefighter. Should be taken in conjunction with Firefighter Certification II, III, IV, V, VI, and VII to satisfy the Texas Commission on Fire Protection (TCFP) curriculum for Basic Structural Fire Suppression, Course #100. ***THIS COURSE MAY BE OFFERED ONLY BY INSTITUTIONS CERTIFIED TRAINING FACILITY BY THE TEXAS COMMISSION ON FIRE PROTECTION (TCFP) ***

Fire Certification I is 1 of 9 co-requisite courses to complete the Texas Commission on Fire Protection curriculum for Basic Structural Firefighter; it is a co-requisite of the first semester of the firefighter certification program and prerequisite to the second semester. Acceptance in this course is conditional to student acceptance of the stringent program policy and rules for successful completion. Course content includes general fire service organization, history, communications, safety, personal protective equipment, self-contained breathing apparatus, fire behavior, and, rope and ladder use. Embedded within this course is study of learning, cognition, and motivation; factors that impact learning, and application of learning strategies.

title: Firefighter Certification II
description:
One in a series of courses in basic preparation for a new firefighter. Should be taken in conjunction with Firefighter Certification I, III, IV, V, VI, and VII to satisfy the Texas Commission on Fire Protection (TCFP) curriculum for Basic Structural Fire Suppression, Course #100. ***THIS COURSE MAY BE OFFERED ONLY BY INSTITUTIONS CERTIFIED AS A TRAINING FACILITY BY THE TEXAS COMMISSION ON FIRE PROTECTION***

Fire Certification II is 1 of 9 co-requisite courses to complete the Texas Commission on Fire Protection curriculum for Basic Structural Firefighter; it is a co-requisite of the first semester of the firefighter certification program and prerequisite to the second semester. Acceptance in this course is conditional to student acceptance of the stringent program policy and rules for successful completion. Course content includes responding to and working at hazardous emergency scenes as part of a team; using fire hose for water supply; maintenance and preparation of fire hose and various firefighting equipment; introduction to fire behavior in Class A, wildland and vehicle fires; the use of water and portable extinguishers to extinguish Class A, wildland, and vehicle fires.

title: Firefighter Certification III
description:
One in a series of courses in basic preparation for a new firefighter. Should be taken in conjunction with Firefighter Certification I, II, IV, V, VI, and VII to satisfy the Texas Commission on Fire Protection (TCFP) curriculum for Basic Structural Fire Suppression, Course #100. ***THIS COURSE MAY BE OFFERED ONLY BY INSTITUTIONS CERTIFIED AS A TRAINING FACILITY BY THE TEXAS COMMISSION ON FIRE PROTECTION***

Fire Certification III is 1 of 9 co-requisite courses to complete the Texas Commission on Fire Protection curriculum for Basic Structural Firefighter it is a co-requisite of the first semester of the firefighter certification program and prerequisite to the second semester. Acceptance in this course is conditional to student acceptance of the stringent program policy and rules for successful completion. Course content includes working as a firefighting team for firefighter survival and to perform search and rescue; establishing functional entry into structures; introduction to structural fire behavior and ventilation of structural fires; overhaul, property conservation.

title: Firefighter Certification IV
description:
One in a series of courses in basic preparation for a new firefighter. Should be taken in conjunction with Firefighter Certification I, II, III, V, VI, and VII to satisfy the Texas Commission on Fire Protection (TCFP) curriculum for Basic Structural Fire Suppression, Course #100. ***THIS COURSE MAY BE OFFERED ONLY BY INSTITUTIONS CERTIFIED AS A TRAINING FACILITY BY THE TEXAS COMMISSION ON FIRE PROTECTION***

Fire Certification IV is 1 of 9 co-requisite courses to complete the Texas Commission on Fire Protection curriculum for Basic Structural Firefighter. Acceptance in this course is conditional to student acceptance of the stringent program policy and rules for successful completion. Course content includes introduction to the roles of the firefighter in the use of Incident command and National Incident Management System in safe coordinated emergency response and mitigation; the roles of the firefighter in safety education, fire prevention, fire investigation, and in pre-incident planning; firefighter roles in special teams, rescue and vehicle extrication.

title: Firefighter Certification V
description:
One in a series of courses in basic preparation for a new firefighter. Should be taken in conjunction with Firefighter Certification I, II, III, IV, VI, and VII to satisfy the Texas Commission on Fire Protection (TCFP) curriculum for Basic Structural Fire Suppression, Course #100. ***THIS COURSE MAY BE OFFERED ONLY BY INSTITUTIONS CERTIFIED AS A TRAINING FACILITY BY THE TEXAS COMMISSION ON FIRE PROTECTION***

Firefighter Certification V is 1 of 9 co-requisite courses to complete the Texas Commission on Fire Protection curriculum for Basic Structural Firefighter. Acceptance in this course is conditional to student acceptance of the stringent program policy and rules for successful completion. Course content includes introduction to Class B behavior and extinguishment; functional coordination of fire ground activities for interior fire attack; a practice of the culmination of all basic structural firefighting knowledge, skills, and abilities.

title: Driver/Operator-Pumper
description:
Meets curriculum requirements of the Texas Commission on Fire Protection
(TCFP) for Driver/Operator-Pumper.

title: Driver Operator/Aerial
description: Meets curriculum requirements of the Texas Commission on Fire Protection (TCFP) for Driver Operator/Aerial.

title: ST Fire Protection Safety Technology (Fire Arson Investigation III)
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description: Topics address recently identified current events, skills, knowledge, and/or attitudes and behaviors pertinent to the technology or occupation and relevant to the professional development of the student. Continuation of Fire and Arson Investigation II . Topics include determination of the origin and cause of a fire.

title: Fundamentals of Fire Protection
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description: Orientation to the fire service, career opportunities, and related fields. This course meets Fire and Emergency Services Higher Education (FESHE) Model Curriculum core requirements.

title: Fire and Arson Investigation I
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description: Basic fire and arson investigation practices. Emphasis on fire behavior principles related to fire cause and origin determination.

title: Public Education Programs
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description: Preparation of firefighters and fire officers to develop public fire safety awareness. Emphasis on implementation of fire and public safety programs in an effort to reduce the loss of life.

title: Fire Codes and Inspections
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description: Local building and fire prevention codes. Fire prevention inspections, practices, and procedures. This course meets Fire and Emergency Services Higher Education (FESHE) Model Curriculum core requirements.

title: Hazardous Materials I
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description:
The chemical characteristics and behavior of various materials. Storage,  transportation, handling hazardous emergency situations, and the methods of hazard mitigation. 
Course content includes introduction to the laws, regulations and national consensus standards dealing with response to hazardous materials; identifying, analyzing, planning and implementing appropriate Awareness Level actions using safety data sheets, labels, product containers, The North American Emergency Response Guide, CHEMTREC Call Center, and environmental factors.

title: Fire Fighter Health and Safety
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description: Firefighter occupational safety and health in emergency and non-emergency situations. This course meets Fire and Emergency Services Higher Education (FESHE) Model Curriculum core requirements.

title: Building Construction in the Fire Service
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description: Components of building construction that relate to life safety. Includes relationship of construction elements and building design impacting fire spread in structures.

title: Fire Protection Systems
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description: Design and operation of fire detection and alarm systems, heat and smoke control systems, special protection and sprinkler systems, water supply for fire protection, and portable fire extinguishers. This course meets Fire and Emergency Services Higher Education (FESHE) Model Curriculum core requirements.

title: Fire Officer I
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description:
Meets the curriculum requirements of the Texas Commission on Fire
Protection (TCFP) for Fire Officer I certification.

title: Fire Officer II
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description: Meets the curriculum requirements of the Texas Commission on Fire Protection (TCFP) for Fire Officer II certification.

title: Special Topics: Basic Wildland Firefighting
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description: Terminology and techniques used in wildland firefighting. Includes wildfire suppression, fire behaviors, mop-up techniques and benefits, safety, and incident management systems.

title: Fire Inspector I
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description:
One in a series of two courses required for Fire Inspector certification. Meets the curriculum requirements of the Texas Commission on Fire Protection (TCFP) for Fire Inspector I. **THIS COURSE MAY BE OFFERED ONLY BY INSTITUTIONS CERTIFIED AS A TRAINING FACILITY BY THE TEXAS COMMISSION ON FIRE PROTECTION**

The Fire Inspector I conducts basic fire inspections and applies codes and standards.

title: Fire Inspector II
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description: One in a series of three courses required for Fire Inspector certification. Meets the curriculum requirements of the Texas Commission on Fire Protection (TCFP) for Fire Inspector II. The Fire Inspector II conducts most types of inspections and interprets applicable codes and standards.

title: Hazardous Materials II
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description:
Mitigation practices and techniques to control hazardous material spills and leaks. 
Hazardous Materials II is 1 of 9 co-requisite courses to complete the Texas Commission on Fire Protection curriculum for Basic Structural Firefighter. Acceptance in this course is conditional to student acceptance of the stringent program policy and rules for successful completion. Course content includes introduction to the laws, regulations and national consensus standards dealing with response to hazardous materials; identifying, analyzing, planning and implementing appropriate Operations and Mission Specific Level actions using safety data sheets, labels, product containers, The North American Emergency Response Guide, CHEMTREC Call Center, and environmental factors.

title: Incident Safety Officer
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description:
Meets the curriculum requirements of the Texas Commission on fire protection (TCFP) for Incident Safety Officer Certification. **THIS COURSE MAY BE OFFERED BY INSTITUTIONS CERTIFIED AS A TRAINING FACILITY BY THE TEXAS COMMISSION ON FIRE PROTECTION.
An Incident Safety Officer is an individual who has met the requirements of Fire Officer Level I specified in NFPA 1021, Standard for Fire Officer Professional Qualifications and Chapter 5 of NFPA 1521, Standard for Fire Department Safety Officer and has the knowledge, skill, and abilities to manage incident scene safety by having and maintaining a knowledge of fire suppression operations,  technical rescue operations, hazardous materials operations, building construction, fire science and behavior relative to predicting hostile fire events. Further knowledge in The Incident Command System, fire department’s personnel accountability system, incident scene rehabilitation strategies, accident investigation and review process, and post-Incident analysis procedures.

title: Hazardous Materials Incident Commander
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description:
Meets the curriculum requirements of the Texas Commission on Fire Protection (TCFP) for Hazardous Materials Incident Commander certification. **THIS COURSE MAY BE OFFERED ONLY BY AN INSTITUTION CERTIFIED AS TRAINING FACILITY BY THE TEXAS COMMISSION ON FIRE PROTECTION. 
A person designated by the AHJ, responsible for all incident activities/operations, including the development of strategies and tactics and the ordering and release of resources at a hazardous materials incident.

title: Fire Instructor I
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description: Preparation of fire and emergency services personnel to deliver instruction from a prepared lesson plan. Includes the use of instructional aids and evaluation instruments to meet the curriculum requirements of the Texas Commission on Fire Protection (TCFP) for Fire Instructor I certification.

title: Fire Instructor II
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description: Development of individual lesson plans for a specific topic including learning objectives, instructional aids, and evaluation instruments. Includes techniques for supervision and coordination of activities of other instructors to meet the curriculum requirements of the Texas Commission on Fire Protection (TCFP) for Fire Instructor II certification.

title: Firefighting Strategies and Tactics I
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description:
Analysis of the nature of fire problems and selection of initial strategies and
tactics including an in-depth study of efficient and effective use of staffing and equipment to mitigate the emergency.

title: Fire and Arson Investigation II
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description: Fire Investigation techniques and defense of findings in a court room setting.

title: Hazardous Materials III
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description:
Mitigation, preparedness, response, and recovery to hazardous materials incidents. 
Hazardous Materials Technician Level Personnel are those who respond to hazardous materials/weapons of mass destruction (WMD) incidents and use a risked based response process to analyze a problem involving hazardous materials/weapons of mass destruction (WMD), select and implement applicable decontamination procedures, control a release, use specialized protective clothing, and use specialized control equipment. Meets curriculum requirements of the Texas Commission on Fire Protection for Hazardous Materials Technician Level.

title: Fire Officer III
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description:
Meets the curriculum requirements of the Texas Commission on Fire Protection (TCFP) for Fire Officer III certification. 
**THIS COURSE MAY BE OFFERED ONLY BY INSTITUTIONS CERTIFIED AS A TRAINING FACILITY BY THE TEXAS COMMISSION ON FIRE PROTECTION.**
A Fire Officer III is a midlevel supervisor who performs both managerial and first-line administrative functions who has met all the job performance and certification requirements of Fire Officer III, in addition to previously meeting all the job performance and certification requirements of Fire Officer II as defined in NFPA 1021, Standard for Fire Officer Professional Qualifications and Fire Instructor II as defined in NFPA 1041, Standard for Fire Service Instructor Professional Qualifications.

title: Fire Officer IV
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description:
Meets the curriculum requirements of the Texas Commission on Fire Protection (TCFP) for Fire Officer IV certification. **THIS COURSE MAY BE OFFERED ONLY BY INSTITUTIONS CERTIFIERD AS A TRAINING FACILITY BY THE TEXAS COMMISSION ON FIRE PROTECTION.**

A Fire Officer IV is an upper level supervisor who performs administrative functions who has met all the job performance and certification requirements of Fire Officer IV, in addition to previously meeting all the job performance and certification requirements of Fire Officer III as defined in NFPA 1021, Standard for Fire Officer Professional Qualifications.

title: Fire Instructor III
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description: Meets the curriculum requirements of the Texas Commission on Fire Protection (TCFP) for Fire Instructor III certification. **THIS COURSE MAY BE OFFERED ONLY BY INSTITUTIONS CERTIFIED AS A TRAINING FACILITY BY THE TEXAS COMMISSION ON FIRE PROTECTION**

title: Incident Commander
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description: An Incident Commander is an individual who has met the requirements of chapter 4 of NFPA 1026, Standard for Incident Management Personnel Professional Qualifications and has the knowledge, skills, and abilities to perform as an Incident Commander. The individual responsible for all incident activities, including the development of strategies and tactics and the ordering and the release of resources. Has overall authority and responsibility for conducting incident operations and for managing all incident operations at the incident site.

title: Co-op Education - Fire Protection
department: FIRT - Fire Protection and Safety Technology/Technician
description: Career-related activities encountered in the student's area of specialization offered through an individualized agreement among the college, employer, and student. Under the supervision of the college and the employer, the student combines classroom learning with work experience. Includes a lecture component.

title: Production Management
description: An introduction to managing above- and below-the-line film or video production costs. Emphasizes analysis of scripts and treatments to determine production costs, crewing requirements, location needs, equipment rentals, and associated production costs.

title: Lighting for Film Or Video
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball,
description: Fundamentals of lighting techniques for film or video production with respect to lighting tools, composition and camera motion to support dynamic storytelling.

title: Video Graphics & Visual Effects I
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park,
description: A course in the applications of computers for video production.  Design of computer graphic workstations and development of a rationale for selecting software, hardware, and peripherals.

title: Video Graphics & Visual Effects II
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park,
description: Designing vector and raster graphics, executing rendering techniques, designing and producing three-dimensional (3-D) materials, and selecting hardware, software, and peripherals for video production.

title: Cinematography
description: Advanced concepts of theoretical elements and practical applications of the cinematic craft.

title: Advanced Film and Video Editing
description: Exploration of the creative possibilities of non-linear film and video editing. Includes editing aesthetics, titles, graphic design, compositing, and special effects.

title: Beginning French I
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,

title: Beginning French II
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: A continuation of FREN 1411 with increased emphasis on comprehension, speaking, reading and writing. Intensive drills to increase vocabulary and knowledge of structure.

title: Intermediate French I
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: French readings, grammar, and composition based partly on the formal text and partly on selected readings. Stress will be placed on oral work.

title: Intermediate French II
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: Continuation of FREN 2311.

title: Intro Game Design & Development
department: GAME - Animation, Interactive Technology, Video Graphics and Special Effects
description: Introduction to electronic game development and game development careers.  Includes examination of history and philosophy of games, the game production process, employee factors for success in the field, and current issues and practices in the game development industry.

title: Level Design
department: GAME - Animation, Interactive Technology, Video Graphics and Special Effects
description: Introduction to the tools and concepts used to create levels for games and simulations. Incorporates level design, architecture theory, concepts of critical path and flow, balancing, play testing, and storytelling.  Includes utilization of toolsets from industry titles.

title: Game and Simulation Programming I
department: GAME - Animation, Interactive Technology, Video Graphics and Special Effects
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, Online,
description: Game and simulation programming. Includes advanced pointer manipulation techniques and pointer applications, points and vectors, sound, and graphics.

title: Game & Simulation Programming II
department: GAME - Animation, Interactive Technology, Video Graphics and Special Effects
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, Online,
description: Design and development of game and simulation programs including user interface design, mathematical elements, image and file structure, and software development techniques.

title: Artificial Intelligence Programming I
department: GAME - Animation, Interactive Technology, Video Graphics and Special Effects
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, Online,
description: Basic techniques in artificial intelligence related to game and simulation programming. Includes knowledge representation and interference techniques, expert systems, pathfinding algorithms, and search techniques for problem solving.

title: Interactive Writing II
department: GAME - Animation, Interactive Technology, Video Graphics and Special Effects
description: Dialog, story, and character development in writing for video games.

title: Video Game Art II
department: GAME - Animation, Interactive Technology, Video Graphics and Special Effects
description: A study of industry-used, game-art techniques and its applications of game art assets. Utilizes tools and advanced techniques in the creation of assets for a game engine.

title: Project Development I
department: GAME - Animation, Interactive Technology, Video Graphics and Special Effects
description: Skill development in an original modification based on a current game engine. Includes management of version control; development of project timelines; integration of sound, models, and animation; production of demos; and creation of original levels, characters, and content for a real-time multiplayer game.

title: Game Testing
department: GAME - Animation, Interactive Technology, Video Graphics and Special Effects
description: Testing and debugging gaming and simulation applications in the alpha and beta stages of production. Includes critiques of the product and written documentation of the testing and debugging processes.

title: Internship-Animation, Interactive Technology, Video Graphics and Special Effects
department: GAME - Animation, Interactive Technology, Video Graphics and Special Effects
description: As outlined in the learning plan, apply the theory, concepts, and skills involving specialized materials, tools, equipment, procedures, regulations, laws, and interactions within and among political, economic, environmental, social, and legal systems associated with the occupation and the business/industry and will demonstrate legal and ethical behavior, safety practices, interpersonal and teamwork skills, and appropriate written and verbal communication skills using the terminology of the occupation and the business/industry.

title: Physical Geography
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: This course introduces students to the processes that drive Earth's physical systems. Students will explore the relationships among these physical systems, with emphasis on weather and climate, water, ecosystems, geologic processes and landform development, and human interactions with the physical environment.

title: Human Geography
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: This course introduces students to fundamental concepts, skills, and practices of human geography. Place, space, and scale serve as a framework for understanding patterns of human experience. Topics for discussion may include globalization, population and migration, culture, diffusion, political and economic systems, language, religion, gender, and ethnicity.

title: World Regional Geography
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: This course is an introduction to the world's major regions seen through their defining physical, social, cultural, political, and economic features. These regions are examined in terms of their physical and human characteristics and their interactions. The course emphasizes relations among regions on issues such as trade, economic development, conflict, and the role of regions in the globalization process. International Studies Area of Concentration course.

campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,

campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: Extension of the study of geology, astronomy, meteorology and oceanography, focusing on natural resources, hazards and climate variability.

title: Physical Geology
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: Physical Geology is a basic science course that focuses on Earth, including its composition, processes of change, history and the tools and methods used to study it.

title: Historical Geology
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: A comprehensive survey of the history of life and major events of the physical development of Earth as interpreted from rocks and fossils.

title: Environmental Geology
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: A survey of the forces, including humans, that shape our physical environment, and how they affect life on Earth. Introduction to the science and policy of global and regional environmental issues, including pollution, climate change, and sustainability of land, water, and energy resources.

title: Oceanography
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: This is an introductory course in Oceanography that explores the interaction of oceans with the earth's four spheres (geosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere, and biosphere). Students develop an understanding of fundamental oceanographic processes, discuss their impacts on society, and evaluate their behavior through a variety of scientific inquiry techniques.

title: Meteorology
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: Survey of meteorology and related science, which explores concepts and principles of meteorological processes; including clouds and precipitation, local and global circulation, air masses and fronts, vertical structure of the atmosphere, severe weather systems, forecasting and modeling, air pollution, and climate change.

title: Academic Cooperative in Geologic Research
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,

Students will work under the supervision of a faculty member after a research project of mutual interest is selected.  Students design and perform laboratory or field investigations and present and defend the results of the project.
