title: Private Applied Music: Composition
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description:
(Second year, 1-hour lesson per week and 1-hour studio class per week)
Private instruction in composition, available to students majoring or minoring in music and to other students who desire to gain or improve proficiency in music composition.

title: Symphony Orchestra
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, Houston North, University Park,
description: The study and performance of music compositions for full orchestra, including strings, woodwinds, brass, and percussion. Recommended for music majors whose principle performance instrument is violin, viola, cello, or string bass. A maximum of four credit hours may be earned.

title: Jazz Ensemble
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: The study and performance of big band jazz. Swing, Latin, rock, and other jazz styles are included. A maximum of four credit hours may be earned.

title: String Ensemble
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: This course involves the study and performances of music compositions for small string groups. It is recommended for music majors whose principle performing medium is the violin, viola, or cello. A maximum of four credit hours may be earned.

title: Piano Ensemble
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park,
description: A course which is designed to offer students an opportunity to work with piano literature written for two or more performers. A maximum of four credit hours may be earned.

title: Percussion Ensemble
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park,
description: This course involves the study and performance of music compositions for percussion groups. It is recommended for music majors whose performing medium is percussion. Open to other qualified students. A maximum of four credit hours may be earned.

title: Steel Drum Band
campus: Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, CyFair, Houston North,
description: Membership is open to all students on the basis of audition and/or conference to assess the students ability to count fundamental rhythms. Percussionist, vocalist, woodwind, brass, and keyboard players are encouraged to audition.  The class meets four hours per week with special rehearsals and performances called as needed. This course may be taken a maximum of four times for credit.

title: Chamber Ensemble
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: Chamber Ensemble is a mixed instrumentation group of wind, string, percussion, and brass players performing chamber (small group) repertoire from any style period. A maximum of four credit hours may be earned.

title: Concert Choir
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park,
description: Concert Choir is a large vocal ensemble performing large-scale sacred and secular works. In addition to a final concert, the group also participates in activities on and/or off campus. The Choir is open to students with vocal experience. A maximum of four credit hours may be earned.

title: Chamber Singers
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, Houston North, University Park,
description: The Chamber Singers are a small vocal ensemble performing sacred and secular choral literature of various eras including madrigals.  A maximum of four credit hours may be earned.

title: Pop Singers I
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: The Pop Singers specialize in performing contemporary popular music, including music of radio, TV, motion picture, and Broadway. Some choreography and staging may be involved.  A maximum of four credit hours may be earned.

title: Symphonic Band
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park,
description: The study and performance of literature for large ensembles of woodwind, brass, and percussion instruments, with the possible addition of double bass. Open to all students with instrumental music experience who play a wind, brass, percussion instrument, or double bass. A maximum of four credit hours may be earned.

title: Woodwind Ensemble I
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, Houston North, University Park,
description: This course involves the study and performance of music compositions for small woodwind groups. It is recommended for music majors whose principle performing medium is a woodwind instrument. A maximum of four credit hours may be earned.

title: Brass Ensemble I
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: This course involves the study and performance of music compositions for small brass groups. It is recommended for music majors whose performing medium is a brass instrument. A maximum of four credit hours may be earned.

title: Jazz Combo
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park,
description: A study of the techniques involved in the improvisation of a solo in the jazz idiom through rehearsal and performance in a small ensemble. Open to all students with instrumental music or vocal jazz experience. A maximum of four credit hours may be earned.

title: Professional Development for Musicians
description: This course will assist students in developing the critical skills required to be successful musicians in the professional world. Students will learn how to write professional résumés, CVs, cover letters, and bios; effective audition, rehearsal, and performance technique; and the basics of music law and music business.

title: Sight Singing and Ear Training I
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: Singing tonal music in treble and bass clefs, and aural study of elements of music, such as scales, intervals and chords, and dictation of basic rhythm, melody and diatonic harmony.

title: Sight Singing and Ear Training II
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: Singing tonal music in various clefs, continued aural study of the elements of music, and dictation of intermediate rhythm, melody and diatonic harmony.

title: Opera Workshop
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: A study of the synthesis of singing and acting through the performance of opera. Students may repeat for four hours of credit. Audition and departmental approval required.

title: Italian Diction
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: A study of the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) and its application to singing in Italian.

title: International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) for Singers
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: A study of the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) and its application to singing in English, Italian, German, and French.

title: Diction I
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, Houston North, University Park,
description: This course provides a framework for singing in English, Latin, and Italian. While some grammatical rules will be taught, the course does not attempt to teach the language.

title: Class Piano Level I
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: Beginning class instruction in the fundamentals of keyboard technique.

title: Class Piano Level II
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: Advanced beginning class instruction in the fundamentals of keyboard technique.

title: Class Voice
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: Class instruction in the fundamentals of singing including breathing, tone production, and diction.  Designed for students with little or no previous voice training.  Does not apply to a music major degree. A maximum of four credit hours of voice classes may be earned.

title: Percussion Class
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: Class instruction in the fundamental techniques of playing percussion instruments.

title: Class Guitar
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: Class instruction in fundamental guitar playing, including technique, music-reading, fretboard theory, melodic and harmonic realizations. A maximum of four credit hours may be earned.

title: Fundamentals of Music
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park,
description: Introduction to the basic elements of music theory, including scales, intervals, keys, triads, elementary ear training, notation, meter, and rhythm.  Course does not apply to a music major degree.

title: Appreciating Music
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: Understanding music through the study of cultural periods, major composers, and musical elements, illustrated with audio recordings and live performances.  Course does not apply to a music major degree.

title: Music Literature
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: A survey of the styles and forms of music as it developed from the middle ages to the present.  This course will familiarize the student with cultural context, terminology, genres, and notation.

title: American Music
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: A general survey of various styles of music of the Americas, including but not limited to jazz, folk, rock, and contemporary music.

title: Music Theory I
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: The study of analysis and writing of tonal melody and diatonic harmony, including fundamental music concepts, scales, intervals, chords, 7th chords, and early four-part writing. Analysis of small compositional forms. Optional correlated study at the keyboard.

title: Music Theory II
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: The study of analysis and writing of tonal melody and diatonic harmony, including all diatonic chords and seventh chords in root position and inversions, non-chord tones, and functional harmony. Introduction to more complex topics, such as modulation, may occur. Optional correlated study at the keyboard.

title: Sight Singing and Ear Training III
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: Singing more difficult tonal music in various clefs, aural study including dictation of more complex rhythm, melody, chromatic harmony, and extended tertian structures.

title: Sight Singing and Ear Training IV
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: Singing advanced tonal music and introduction of modal and post-tonal melodies. Aural study including dictation of advanced rhythm, melody, and harmony.

title: German Diction
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: A study of the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) and its application to singing in German.

title: French Diction
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: A study of the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) and its application to singing in French.

title: Class Piano Level III
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: Intermediate class instruction of keyboard technique.

title: Class Piano Level IV
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: Advanced class instruction of keyboard technique.

title: Music Theory III
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: Advanced harmony voice leading, score analysis and writing of more advanced tonal harmony including chromaticism and extended-tertian structures. Optional correlated study at the keyboard.

title: Music Theory IV
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North,
description: Continuation of advanced chromaticism and survey of analytical and compositional procedures in post-tonal music. Optional correlated study at the keyboard.

title: Academic Co-op In Music
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, Houston North, University Park,
description: An instructional program designed to integrate on-campus study with practical hands-on work experience in music. In conjunction with class seminars, the instructor and institutional representative, the individual student will set specific goals and objectives in music.

title: Honors Appreciating Music
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: Understanding music through the study of cultural periods, major composers, and musical elements, illustrated with audio recordings and live performances.  Course does not apply to a music major degree.

title: Honors Music Literature
campus: Montgomery, CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: A survey of the styles and forms of music as it developed from the middle ages to the present.  This course will familiarize the student with cultural context, terminology, genres, and notation.

title: Honors American Music
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: A general survey of various styles of music of the Americas, including but not limited to jazz, folk, rock, and contemporary music.

title: Piano Proficiency Exam
description: Piano Proficiency Exam. Exam required to pass out of the 1-4 hours of piano proficiency courses required in the degree plan.

title: Film Interpretation of Weldments
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball,
description: A study of radiographic film, including exploration of radiographic basics, interpretation, and causes and effects of discontinuities.

title: Liquid Penetrant/Magnetic Particle
description:
A theoretical study and practical application of the non-destructive testing
techniques of penetrant and magnetic particle testing required by quality assurance and test personnel.

title: Eddy Current Testing
description: General principles of Eddy Current Testing including theory, knowledge, and skills for basic examination; effects of material properties, probe types, calibration standards, and equipment selection.

title: Intermediate Ultrasonics
description:
Applications of the ultrasonic techniques of materials testing for flaw sizing
and characterization.

title: Advanced Ultrasonics
description:
Emphasis on examination of components and, characterization of flaws
using advanced techniques.

title: Preparation for Cert Weld Inspector Exam
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball,
description: Welding fundamentals, welding inspection and code interpretation in preparation for the certified welding inspector examination.

title: Radiation Protection I
description: Introduction to the field of radiation protection: the art and science of protecting human beings from injury by radiation. Topics include dose and exposure measurements and units, permissible exposure limits, and internal exposure evaluations.

title: Clinical – Nursing Assistant/Aide and Patient Care Assistant/Aide
description: A health-related work-based learning experience that enables the student to apply specialized occupational theory, skills, and concepts. Direct supervision is provided by the clinical professional.

title: Nurse Aide for Health Care
description: Knowledge, skills, and abilities essential to provide basic care to residents of long-term care facilities. Topics include resident's rights, communication, safety, observation, reporting and assisting residents in maintaining basic comfort and safety. Emphasis on effective interaction with members of the health care team, restorative services, mental health, and social services needs.

title: Transition to Baccalaureate Nursing
description: This course will focus on the synthesis of previous knowledge and skills to provide the foundation for development of the baccalaureate prepared nursing roles as a provider of patient centered care, patient safety advocate, member of the interdisciplinary team, and member of the profession.

title: Introduction to Nursing Research
description: This course focuses on introduction to the basic concepts, processes, and applications of nursing research as a foundation for evidenced-based practice; promoting appraisal skills in the role of the nurse to support evidence-based, patient-centered care, quality improvement, and safety outcomes.

title: Informatics and Technology in Healthcare
description: This course establishes the role of electronic information infrastructure in the delivery of care within the institution and interdisciplinary care team. Focus of this course includes the utilization of informatics to access data to enhance quality and continuity of care in a variety of health care settings.

title: Legal and Ethical Issues in Healthcare
description: This course discusses the application of legal and ethical principles related to the practice of nursing in differing areas of practice.

title: Nursing Today - Issues and Trends in Professional Nursing Practice
description: This course examines major issues and trends in contemporary nursing and healthcare practice, the influence of socioeconomic, workforce and workplace issues, political variables, professional values, and the changes in the U.S. health care delivery system.

title: Community and Public Health Clinical
description: This course provides a health-related work-based learning experience within the community setting.

title: Leadership and Management Clinical
description: This course emphasizes leadership and management theories in communication and conflict resolution, budgeting, human resource management, quality and safety, risk management, change, delegation, decision making, and current issues and trends. Clinical experiences focus on management of issues and interactive observation of leaders and managers in a variety of settings.

title: Community and Public Health Nursing - Practicum
description: This course will focus on practice experience using the population-focused nursing process in various community and public health organizations which serve a variety of patients across the lifespan, families, and communities.

title: Leadership and Management - Practicum
description: This course will focus on practice experience using the population-focused nursing process in various community and public health organizations which serve a variety of patients across the lifespan, families, and communities.

title: Community and Public Health
description: This course will explore the role of the community/public health nurse caring for individuals, families, communities, and populations. It is through designing, implementing, evaluating population-based interventions that promote the health of a community and its members. In addition, community health promotion includes disease/injury prevention within vulnerable and at-risk populations.

title: Health Promotion Across the Lifespan
description: This course examines health promotion across the lifespan, including pediatric, adult, and geriatric populations. Emphasis is placed upon health and environmental patterns that promote or interfere with health attainment and risk reduction in the identified populations.

title: Leadership and Management
description: This course focuses on exploration of organizational strategies, leadership theories, and societal trends with implication for decision-making in healthcare.  Management techniques and nursing care decisions are examined by synthesizing knowledge of various health care organizations.

title: Population Focused Community Health
description: This combined theory and clinical course will explore the role of the community/public health nurse caring for individuals, families, communities, and populations through designing, implementing, and evaluating population-based interventions that promote the health of a community and its members. Emphasis is given to health promotion and disease/injury prevention within vulnerable and at-risk populations and minimizing health consequences of emergency and disaster situations. Entry-level competencies for public health nurses are developed through diverse clinical experiences in virtual and real-world settings.

title: Synthesis / RN to BSN Capstone Project
description: This course will focus on a scholarly exchange that will demonstrate the students' knowledge of doing research in a clinical or theoretical problem in nursing.  Findings to support evidence-based, patient-centered care, quality improvement, and/or safety outcomes.  Includes a written and oral component.

title: Leadership & Management
description: This course explores leadership and management theories, resource allocation, the nurse as a change agent, member of the profession, communication, and quality improvement in the healthcare setting.

title: Academic Readiness and Review I
description: This course provides academic support and supplemental instruction to lifePATH® students during their first semester.

title: Academic Readiness and Review II
description: This course provides academic support and supplemental instruction to lifePATH® students during their second semester.

title: Academic Readiness and Review III
description: This course provides academic support and supplemental instruction to lifePATH® students during their third semester.

title: Academic Readiness and Review IV
description: This course provides academic support and supplemental instruction to lifePATH® students during their fourth semester.

title: Academic Readiness & Review V
description: This course provides academic support and supplemental instruction to lifePATH® students during their fifth semester.

title: Academic Readiness and Review 6
description: This course provides academic support and supplemental instruction to lifePATH® students during their sixth semester.

title: Academic Readiness and Review 7
description: This course provides academic support and supplemental instruction to lifePATH® students during their seventh semester.

title: Academic Readiness and Review 8
description: This course provides academic support and supplemental instruction to lifePATH® students during their sixth semester.

title: Business Composition
description: This course will cover writing skills expected in the workplace: organizing ideas into clear, effective, and persuasive documents. Students will review grammar, use various formats and tools to develop ideas, organize outlines, and follow expected format using appropriate introductions and conclusions. Writing topics and formats will reflect those necessary and common in the business world; creating resumes, writing and responding to emails, creating notes for supervisors, as well as writing to resolve problems and advocate for self.

title: Mathematic Essentials
description: The focus of this course is skill development in business math problem solving using technology. Students will engage in critical thinking in or order to solve business related problems using spreadsheet software and/or electronic calculator/keyboard.

title: Self-Awareness & Personal Change
description: This course is all about using the power within to control thoughts, emotions, and results in life. Students will be introduced to strategies to help widen the view of personal commitment, responsibility, and accountability from self to the social world. Students will also learn to understand, self-evaluate, and strengthen their social understanding and social comfort.

title: Wellness Lifestyle I
description: This course will promote healthy lifestyle choices to establish and maintain high levels of wellness and contribute positively to interpersonal relationships and personal achievement. Emphasizes wellness and health promotion in areas that concern students such as assertiveness, communication, healthy relationships, intimacy, and conflicts. Students will also explore and understand the complexity of personal needs and how they can impact relationships.

title: Wellness Lifestyle II
description: This purpose of this course is to provide researched based information pertaining to intimacy, sexual health, emotional wellness, and an individuals right to make decision about sexuality and intimacy, for themselves. Students will explore the complexity of personal needs for fulfillment of life and learn to advocate for their own needs.

title: Stress in the Workplace I
description: The objective of this course is to help students recognize the unspoken rules of the workplace and understand how they affect workplace culture and expectations. This course is in collaboration and partnership with the lifePATH internship manager and associated internship activities.

title: Stress in the Workplace II
description: The objective of this course is to move students toward higher levels of independence as they implement strategies and develop tools to help them recognize norms pertaining to the unspoken rules of the specific industry in which they anticipate building a career. This course is in collaboration and partnership with the lifePATH internship manager and associated internship activities.

title: Interpersonal Relationships
description: This course will help students identify areas for personal development to enhance their relationships with others. Students will be introduced the various components of the social world and how they interplay and impact interpersonal relationships.

title: Effective Communication
description: The course will cover the application of professional communication within business and professional contexts, including academic settings. Students will learn the communication process, communication barriers, active listening, conflict resolution, non-verbal communication, fostering productive conversations and interactions, and giving presentations.

title: Organizational Teamwork
description: This course will provide students the opportunity to synthesize previously learned concepts pertaining to interpersonal relationships, building support networks, and using effective communication in order participate and problem solve effectively in teams. Students apply problem-solving skills to real-world situations, evaluate and capitalize on their personal strengths, and practice strategies for dealing with challenges unique to participating in teams.

title: Networking & Customer Service
description: This course will cover techniques, tools, and expectations in delivering quality customer service in a variety of work environments. Students will study the importance of building relationships (networking) within the workplace in order to more effectively problem solve and deliver quality service to customers. Real world scenarios will provide students an opportunity to practice excellent customer service in person, by phone, and online; handling complaints, dealing with difficult customers, and accessing support networks when necessary.

title: History of Integration & Advocacy
description: This course will cover the history of disability laws in the United States and current laws pertaining to both academic settings and the workplace. Students will research and evaluate personal strengths and challenges pertaining to choice of career, using discretion when disclosing, the use of advocacy skills, building and accessing social supports, and engaging in effective communication in order to meet workplace needs.

title: Career Cluster Research
description: In this course, students will learn to use strategies and tools to develop realistic career goals. Topics emphasized include decision-making and critical thinking, assessment for greater self-awareness, and research techniques for gathering occupational information. Upon successful course completion, students will be able to understand the career decision-making process, identify/confirm career related abilities, interests, and values, apply career investigation skills, and analyze viability of career areas of interest.

title: Career Path Exploration
description: This course will provide opportunities for students to use knowledge of their personal strengths and challenges to develop, or further refine, realistic career goals based on preferences, values, abilities, short and long-term goals, and educational desires. Inventories, assessments, and independent research will guide self-reflection and critical thinking pertaining to potential career choices.

title: Campus RAMP I
description: Students participate in Campus RAMP I (Readiness Assessment Mentorship Program) mentoring experience that will help them generalize the soft skills learned in classes to a new campus setting and further refine the soft skills necessary for their self-identified career goals. This course is in collaboration with and in partnership with required mentoring activities and lifePATH internship manager.

title: Campus RAMP II
description: Students participate in Campus RAMP II (Readiness Assessment Mentorship Program) job shadow experience that will help them generalize and further refine the soft skills necessary for their self-identified career goals. This course is in collaboration and partnership with the lifePATH internship manager.

title: Self-Determined Career
description: In this course, students will review and synthesize their previous research and acquired knowledge and skills to actively pursue their potential career path. Students will evaluate feedback from previous internship experiences to strengthen skillset and understanding of workplace expectations. During the course of the semester, students will identify specific positions of interest, research details, and collaborate with the Internship Coordinator in preparation for internship during year four.

title: Transition to Career I
description: The purpose of this course is to guide students in their understanding and application of soft skills acquired and their necessity in the workplace. Students will use previous professional experience to further develop qualities, skills, and traits for a more robust campus job shadow experience. This course is in collaboration and partnership with RAMP II activities and lifePATH internship manager.

title: Transition to Career II
description: The purpose of this course is to further extend students understanding and application of soft skills acquired and their necessity in the workplace, specifically in the environment in which they anticipate completing their community internship. Students will reflect on prior learning and work experiences in order to analyze skills and develop individualized tools necessary to assist with their transition to a community internship. This course is in collaboration and partnership with the lifePATH internship manager and associated preparation activities for community internship.

title: Community Internship I
description: The purpose of this course is to provide a community-based work experience that allows students to apply the knowledge and skills they have acquired during lifePATH® courses and their campus RAMP to a business environment. The internship site is selected through a collaborative process and is meant to be of benefit to the students established career goals.

title: Community Internship II
description: The purpose of this course is to provide a second community-based work experience that allows students to apply the knowledge and skills they have acquired during lifePATH® courses and their campus internships to a business environment. The internship site is selected through a collaborative process and is meant to be of benefit to the student's established career goals.

title: Material Handling
department: OSHT - Occupational Safety and Health Technology/Technician
description: Proper methods for material handling and storage including safety practices, proper equipment usage, engineering controls, and personal protective equipment.

title: Occupational Performance from Birth to Adolescence
description: Occupational performance of newborns through adolescents. Includes frames of reference, evaluation tools and techniques, and intervention strategies.

title: Occupational Performance for  Elders
description: Occupational performance of elders. Includes frames of reference, evaluation tools and techniques, and intervention strategies.

title: Intro to Occupational Therapy
description: Introduction to the historical development and philosophy of the profession of occupational therapy. Emphasis on the roles and functions of the occupational therapy assistant in current health care environments including moral, legal, and ethical issues.

title: Human Structure and Function in Occupational Therapy
description: Study of the biomechanics of human motion. Emphasis on the musculoskeletal system including skeletal structure, muscles and nerves, and biomechanical assessment procedures.

title: Therapeutic Use of Occupations I
description: Various occupations or activities used as therapeutic interventions in occupational therapy.  Emphasis on awareness of activity demands, contexts, adapting, grading, and safe implementation of occupations or activities.

title: Therapeutic Interventions I
description: Concepts, techniques, and assessments leading to proficiency in skills and activities used as treatment interventions in occupational therapy (OT). Emphasizes the occupational therapy assistant's role in the OT process.

title: Clinical - Occupational Therapy Assistant
description: A health-related work-based learning experience that enables the student to apply specialized occupational theory, skills, and concepts. Direct supervision is provided by the clinical professional. Requires LSC liability insurance.

title: Practicum - Occupational Therapy
description: Practical, general workplace training supported by an individualized learning plan developed by the employer, college, and student.

title: Pathophysiology in Occupational Therapy
description: Pathology and general health management of diseases and injuries across the lifespan encountered in occupational therapy treatment settings. Includes etiology, symptoms, and the client's physical and psychosocial reactions to disease and injury.

title: Therapeutic Use of Occupations or Activities II
description: Emphasis on advanced techniques and applications used in traditional and non-traditional practice settings.

title: Mental Health in Occupational Therapy
description: Promotion of mental health and wellness through occupational therapy.  Topics include theory and intervention strategies to enhance occupational performance.

title: Physical Function in Occupational Therapy
description: Physical function to promote occupational performance. Includes frames of reference, evaluative tools, intervention strategies, and consumer education.

title: Health Care Management in Occupational Therapy
description: Explores the roles of the occupational therapy assistant in health care delivery. Topics include documentation, reimbursement, credentialing, ethical standards, health care team role delineation, and management.

title: Clinical - Occupational Therapy Assistant
description: A health-related work-based learning experience that enables the student to apply specialized occupational theory, skills, and concepts. Direct supervision is provided by the clinical professional. Requires LSC liability insurance.

title: Clinical - OT Assistant
description: A health-related work-based learning experience that enables the student to apply specialized occupational theory, skills, and concepts. Direct supervision is provided by the clinical professional.

title: Clinical - OT Assistant
description: A health-related work-based learning experience that enables the student to apply specialized occupational theory, skills, and concepts. Direct supervision is provided by the clinical professional.

title: Special Topics in Plumbing Technology/Plumber
description: Identification, installation, and testing of piping systems and their components. Nondestructive test methods will be used to insure piping system quality and safety.

title: Basic Blueprint Reading for Pipefitters
description: Reading interpreting and sketching piping drawings. Includes isometric and orthographic views.

title: Basic Pipefitting Skills
description: Mathematical operations necessary to calculate laying lengths of pipe fittings for fabrication. Identification and use of hand tools and power tools. Identification of pipe, pipe fittings, flanges, and fasteners used in the trade.

title: Intermediate Blueprint Reading for Pipefitters
description: Reading and interpreting advanced working drawings to calculate piping runs. Includes instrumentation symbols and abbreviations and the use of advanced sketching techniques to create isometric and orthographic drawings of piping and piping components.

title: Pipe Fabrication and Installation I
description: Pipe fabrication and various materials and installation of pipe supports.

title: Piping Standards and Materials
description: Identification, description, and application of piping standards and specifications. Includes identification and use of various metallic and non-metallic piping materials, identification and installation of valves, and material take-offs.

title: Advanced Pipefitting Standards, Specifications, and Installation
description: Skill development in motorized equipment, above-ground pipe installation valves, field routing and vessel trim, spring can supports, testing piping systems and equipment, basic plumbing, planning work activities, and Non-Destructive Testing (NDT). Departmental approval required.

title: Pipe Fabrication and Installation II
description: Advanced pipe fabrication of various materials with emphasis on vertical, horizontal, and rolling off-sets using 45-degree fittings and odd-angle fittings.

title: Weight Training I
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: This course emphasizes the development of muscular strength and endurance, cardiovascular fitness, and flexibility. Current information and research in the areas of nutrition, proper training techniques, workout organizations, complementary exercises, and additional wellness principles are presented and integrated into this physical activity course.

title: Karate I
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: This beginning course allows students to safely practice the physical and mental aspects of martial arts. Students are presented with the history, etiquette, meditation, and self-defense techniques.

title: Yoga I
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: This introductory course offers practice in basic Yoga.  Students study history and basic terms along with philosophical and physiological principles and the movements of Yoga.

title: Basketball I
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: This course includes the fundamental skills and strategies, history, rules, and terminology of basketball. The course includes participation in game situations.

title: Volleyball I
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, Houston North, Online, University Park,
description: Volleyball I includes instruction and practice of beginning volleyball techniques and skills, with introduction to the rules, offensive and defensive strategy, and safety aspects.

title: Softball I
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, Online, University Park, Houston North,
description: Students will receive instruction in the following fundamental skill areas: throwing, batting, fielding, and base running. The rules, safety, offense and defense strategies, and basic terminology will be emphasized through game play.

title: Introduction to Physical Fitness & Wellness
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: This course will provide an overview of the lifestyle necessary for fitness and health. Students will participate in physical activities and assess their fitness status. Students will be introduced to proper nutrition, weight management, cardiovascular health, flexibility, and strength training.

title: Foundations of Kinesiology
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: The purpose of this course is to provide students with an introduction to human movement that includes the historical development of physical education, exercise science, and sport. This course offers the student both an introduction to the knowledge base, as well as, information on expanding career opportunities.

title: Personal/Community Health
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: This course provides an introduction to the fundamentals, concepts, strategies, applications, and contemporary trends related to understanding personal and/or community health issues. This course also focuses on empowering various populations with the ability to practice healthy living, promote healthy lifestyles, and enhance individual well-being.

title: First Aid
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: Instruction and practice for emergency care. Designed to enable students to recognize and avoid hazards within their environment, to render intelligent assistance in case of accident or sudden illness, and to develop skills necessary for the immediate and temporary care of the victim. Successful completion of the course may enable the student to receive a certificate from a nationally recognized agency.

title: Kinesiology - Elementary Ed Majors
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: Kinesiology for elementary education majors is a state required three-hour course for Kinesiology (physical education) majors and minors. Theoretical principles, including the four domains of movement, school observations, recognizing the different approaches needed for teaching movement to children vs. adults, and understanding the realistic issues confronting the contemporary elementary educator are discussed.

title: Drug Use & Abuse
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: Study of the use, misuse and abuse of drugs and other harmful substances in today's society. Physiological, sociological, pharmacological and psychological factors will be emphasized.

title: Weight Training II
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: Weight Training II is a continuation of KINE 1112, in which students apply muscular strength, flexibility, endurance, and wellness concepts learned in KINE 1112.

title: Karate II
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, Houston North, Online, University Park,
description: Students will work on intermediate karate skills and techniques and participate in the leadership aspects of this sport.

title: Yoga II
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: This course is a continuation of Yoga I.  The course will offer intermediate level practice of Yoga.  Students will study the history and intermediate terms along with philosophical principles of the movements and Yoga as a concept.

title: Introduction To Philosophy
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: A study of major issues in philosophy and/or the work of major philosophical figures in philosophy. Topics in philosophy may include theories of reality, theories of knowledge, theories of value, and their practical applications.

title: Introduction To World Religions
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: A comparative study of world religions, including but not limited to Hinduism, Buddhism, Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.  International Studies Area of Concentration course.

title: Academic Cooperative
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: An instructional program designed to integrate on-campus study with practical hands-on work experience.  In conjunction with class seminars, the individual student will set specific goals and objectives in the study of philosophy.

title: Introduction to Formal Logic
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: The purpose of the course is to introduce the student to symbolic logic, including syllogisms, propositional and predicate logic, and logical proofs in a system of rules.

title: Introduction to Ethics
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: The systematic evaluation of classical and/or contemporary ethical theories concerning the good life, human conduct in society, morals, and standards of value.

title: Introduction to Social and Political Philosophy
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: A study of major issues in social and political theory and/or the work of major philosophical figures in this area.

title: Classical Philosophy
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: Study of major philosophers and philosophical themes from the ancient through medieval periods.

title: Philosophy Of Religion
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: A study of the major issues in the philosophy of religion such as the existence and nature of God, the relationships between faith and reason, the nature of religious language, religious experience, and the problem of evil.

title: Academic Cooperative
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: An instructional program designed to integrate on-campus study with practical hands-on work experience.  In conjunction with class seminars, the individual student will set specific goals and objectives in the study of philosophy.

title: Honors Introduction To Philosophy
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: A study of major issues in philosophy and/or the work of major philosophical figures in philosophy. Topics in philosophy may include theories of reality, theories of knowledge, theories of value, and their practical applications.

title: Honors Introduction to World Religions
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: A comparative study of world religions, including but not limited to Hinduism, Buddhism, Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.  International Studies Area of Concentration course.

title: Honors Introduction to Formal Logic
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: The purpose of this course is to introduce the student to symbolic logic, including syllogisms, propositional and predicate logic, and logical proofs in a system of rules.

title: Honors Introduction to Ethics
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: The systematic evaluation of classical and/or contemporary ethical theories concerning the good life, human conduct in society, morals, and standards of value.

title: Honors Introduction to Social and Political Philosophy
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: A study of major issues in social and political theory and/or the work of major philosophical figures in this area.

title: Honors Classical Philosophy
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: Study of major philosophers and philosophical themes from the ancient through medieval periods.

title: Honors Philosophy of Religion
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: A study of the major issues in the philosophy of religion such as the existence and nature of God, the relationships between faith and reason, the nature of religious language, religious experience, and the problem of evil.

title: Pharmacy Law
description: Overview of federal and state laws governing the practice of pharmacy. The role of the pharmacy technician and the pharmacist and their associated responsibilities. Includes Code of Ethics, patient confidentiality, and a comparison of legal and ethical aspects.

title: Pharmacy Technician Certification Review
description: A review of major topics covered on the national Pharmacy Technician Certification Examination (PTCE), Exam for the Certification of Pharmacy Technicians (ExCPT).

title: Practicum - Pharmacy Technician
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball,
description: Practical general workplace training supported by an individualized learning plan developed by the employer, college, and student.

title: Pharmacy Law
description: Overview of federal and state laws governing the practice of pharmacy. The role of the pharmacy technician and the pharmacist and their associated responsibilities. Includes Code of Ethics, patient confidentiality, and a comparison of legal and ethical aspects.

title: Comp Drug Delivery Systems I
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball,
description: Fundamentals of computer information systems and technology within the health care system. Includes specialized skills in the production of pharmaceutical documentation using selected pharmacy software packages and an overview of equipment and devices for drug distribution, preparation, and manufacturing.  Also covers mechanical, automatic, and robotic drug delivery systems..

title: Pharmacy Third Party Payment
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball,
description: Overview of third party payment and its impact on health care. Includes the principles and practices of managed care pharmacy, Medicaid and Medicare, payment plans, reimbursement methods, and formularies.

title: Pharmacotherapy and Disease Process
description: A study of disease processes and the therapeutic properties of the drugs used in treatment.

title: Drug Classification
description: A study of pharmaceutical drugs, abbreviations, classifications, indications, dosages, side effects, and routes of administration.

title: Pharmaceutical Mathematics I
description: Solving pharmaceutical calculation problems encountered in the preparation and distribution of drugs.

title: Compounding Sterile Preparations
description: The process of compounding sterile preparations and aseptic technique within legal and regulatory guidelines specified by USP standards.

title: Pharmaceutical Mathematics II
description: Advanced concepts of Pharmaceutical Mathematics.

title: Clinical - Community Pharmacy
description: A health-related work-based learning experience that enables the student to apply specialized occupational theory, skills, and concepts. Direct supervision is provided by the clinical professional. Requires LSC liability insurance.

title: Pharmacy Management Profession Skills
description: Current practices and trends in pharmacy, including advanced pharmacy management skills. This course will prepare students for the pharmacy profession by keeping them updated on current laws, policies and procedure changes, and inter-professional relations in healthcare.

title: Advanced Practice Skills for Pharmacy Technicians
description: This course introduces advanced pharmacy concepts and knowledge to enhance pharmacy technicians’ skills including pharmacy managerial skills, immunizations and administration, advanced pharmacy compounding on sterile and non-sterile compounding, medication therapy management, advanced pharmacy technology, inter-professional relations, etc.

title: Special Topics in Pharmacy Technician/Assistant
description:
Topics address recently identified current events, skills, knowledge, and/or attitudes and behaviors pertinent to the technology or occupation and relevant to the professional development of the student. This course was designed to be repeated multiple times to improve student proficiency. 
This course will prepare the students for their profession by keeping them updated to current laws, policies and procedure changes. This course can be used for specialty certifications in pharmacy such as compounding, chemotherapy and pediatric doses certification.

title: Community Pharmacy Practice
description: Introduction to the skills necessary to process, prepare, label, and maintain records of prescriptions in a community pharmacy to include customer service, count and pour techniques, prescription calculations, drug selection and preparation, over-the-counter drugs, inventory management and legal parameters.

title: Institutional Pharmacy Practice
description: Fundamentals of the diverse roles and practice of pharmacy technicians in an institutional pharmacy setting. In-depth coverage of hospital pharmacy organization, work flow and personnel, safety techniques, data entry, packaging and labeling operations, inpatient drug distribution systems including investigational drugs, continuous quality improvement and inventory control.

title: Clinical II Institutional Pharmacy
description: A health-related work-based learning experience that enables the student to apply specialized occupational theory, skills, and concepts. Direct supervision is provided by the clinical professional. Requires LSC liability insurance.

title: Fundamentals of Photography
description: An introduction to camera operation and image production, composition, supplemental lighting, and use of exposure meters and filters. This course covers the operation of a digital camera and the proper use of photographic equipment.

title: Illustrative Photography I
description: Instruction in the technical aspects involved in commercial photography. Topics include lighting equipment, techniques of production photography, reproduction principles, illustrative techniques, and advertising.

title: Intermediate Photography
description: Continuation of "Fundamentals of Photography." Emphasizes social, portrait, studio, fashion, theatrical, publicity, and event photography. Covers some aspects of photojournalism.

title: Photo Digital Imaging II
description: Advanced concepts in the use of the computer and software for photographic manipulation and output.

title: College Physics I
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: Fundamental principles of physics, using algebra and trigonometry; the principles and applications of classical mechanics and thermodynamics, including harmonic motion, mechanical waves and sound, physical systems, Newton's Laws of Motion, and gravitation and other fundamental forces; with emphasis on problem solving. Laboratory activities will reinforce fundamental principles of physics. This course can serve as the physics requirement for the pre-professional medical programs but does not satisfy the physics requirements for physical science and engineering majors.

title: College Physics II
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: This course is a continuation of PHYS 1401. Fundamental principles of physics, using algebra and trigonometry; the principles and applications of electricity and magnetism, including circuits, electrostatics, electromagnetism, waves, sound, light, optics, and modern physics topics; with emphasis on problem solving. Laboratory activities will reinforce fundamental principles of physics.  This course can serve as the physics requirement for the pre-professional medical programs but does not satisfy the physics requirements for physical science and engineering majors.

title: Stars and Galaxies
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: This is an introductory course that will concentrate on the origin, life and fate of stars, galaxies, and the universe outside our solar system, including the exploration of the universe by astronomers and the understanding of the principles that lie behind the functioning of the universe. An appropriate laboratory program may include real-time telescope observations, field trips and experience with more advanced observing techniques. This is a course for non-science majors who need natural science credit or anyone who wants to study the wonders of the universe.

title: Solar System
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Houston North, Online,
description: This is an introductory course that will concentrate on the origin and life of the sun and its solar system, the various bodies in the solar system and solar system mechanics. An appropriate laboratory program may include real-time telescope observations, field trips and internet research. This is a course for non-science majors who need natural science credit or anyone who wants to study the wonders of the universe.

title: Elementary Physics
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: Conceptual level survey of topics in physics intended for liberal arts and other non-science majors. This course offers the opportunities for the students to explore the basic principles in motion, matter, heat, sound, electricity, light, and modern physics. It includes an appropriate laboratory program.

title: University Physics I
campus: CyFair, Houston North, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: Fundamental principles of physics, using calculus, for physical science, computer science, and engineering majors; the principles and applications of classical mechanics, including harmonic motion, physical systems and thermodynamics; and emphasis on problem solving. Laboratory activities include experimental design, data collection and analysis, and preparation of laboratory reports.

title: Clinical – Phlebotomy/Phlebotomist
description: A health-related work-based learning experience that enables the student to apply specialized occupational theory, skills, and concepts. Direct supervision is provided by the clinical professional.

title: Phlebotomy
description: Skill development in the performance of a variety of blood collection methods using proper techniques and standard precautions. Includes vacuum collection devices, syringes, capillary skin puncture, butterfly needles and blood culture, and specimen collection on adults, children, and infants. Emphasis on infection prevention, patient identification, specimen labeling, quality assurance, specimen handling, processing, accessioning, professionalism, ethics, and medical terminology.

title: Basic Medical Coding
department: POFM - Medical Administrative/Executive Assistant and Medical Secretary
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball,
description: Presentation and application of basic coding rules, principles, guidelines, and conventions utilizing various coding systems.

department: POFM - Medical Administrative/Executive Assistant and Medical Secretary
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball,

department: POFM - Medical Administrative/Executive Assistant and Medical Secretary
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball,
description: Instruction in medical office procedures including appointment scheduling, medical records creation and maintenance, telephone communications, coding, billing, collecting, and third party reimbursement.

title: Medical Insurance
department: POFM - Medical Administrative/Executive Assistant and Medical Secretary
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball,
description: Survey of medical insurance including the life cycle of various claim forms, terminology, patient relations, and legal and ethical issues.

title: Intermediate Medical Coding
department: POFM - Medical Administrative/Executive Assistant and Medical Secretary
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball,
description: Assignment and application of various coding guidelines with emphasis on physician billing and regulatory requirements.  Includes code selection for Evaluation and Management (E/M) and Medical/Surgical cases.

title: Medical Document Production
department: POFM - Medical Administrative/Executive Assistant and Medical Secretary
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball,
description: Create, format and produce publishable medical documents.

description: Career-related activities encountered in the student's area of specialization offered through an individualized agreement among the college, employer, and student. campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball,

department: POFT - General Office /Clerical and Typing Services
description: Examines gender, cultural background, age, and other factors affecting coworker/client relationships. Includes behavioral expectations and standards in the business environment.

department: POFT - General Office /Clerical and Typing Services
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,

department: POFT - General Office /Clerical and Typing Services
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, Online,
description: Study of current office procedures, duties, and responsibilities applicable in an office environment. Keyboarding proficiency recommended.

title: Business Math Using Technology
department: POFT - General Office /Clerical and Typing Services
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park, Online,
description: Skill development in business math problem-solving using technology.

title: Beginning Keyboarding
department: POFT - General Office /Clerical and Typing Services
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, University Park,
description: Skill development keyboarding techniques. Emphasis on development of acceptable speed and accuracy levels and formatting basic documents.

title: Administrative Project Solutions
department: POFT - General Office /Clerical and Typing Services
campus: CyFair, Kingwood, Montgomery, North Harris, Tomball, Online,
description: Advanced concepts of project management and office procedures integrating software applications, critical thinking, and problem-solving skills.

department: POFT - General Office /Clerical and Typing Services
